case_name: Assessee (partnership firm running sugar mill at Cawnpore) v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order of the High Court of Allahabad dated July 16, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: K. Das, J. This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order of the High Court of Allahabad dated July 16, 1956, by which the said High Court decided a question referred to it under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, against the assessee.

facts.text: The High Court decided a question referred to it under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: by which the said High Court decided a question referred to it under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, against the assessee. The question was in these terms Whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a notice under section 28 of the Income-tax Act in circumstances of the case of the applicant in respect of the item of Rs. 76,836 ?

facts.text: The assessee is a partnership firm which ran a sugar mill at Cawnpore for the manufacture of sugar involving conversion of gur into sugar.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, appellant before us, is a partnership firm which ran a sugar mill at Cawnpore and assessee for the manufacture of sugar involved the companyversion of gur into sugar.

facts.text: Relevant assessment year is 1942-43, account year being October 1, 1940 to September 30, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: In the relevant assessment year 1942-43, the account year being October 1, 1940, to September 30, 1941, the assessee submitted a return of income and on the basis of that return the Income-tax Officer concerned made an assessment on November 30, 1944.

facts.text: Assessee submitted a return of income for the relevant year.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee submitted a return of income and on the basis of that return the Income-tax Officer concerned made an assessment on November 30, 1944.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer made an assessment on November 30, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer concerned made an assessment on November 30, 1944. When making the assessment the Income-tax Officer added two sums of Rs. 63,954 and Rs. 76,836.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer added Rs. 63,954 in respect of market value of goods in factory in process of conversion from gur into sugar at closing stock.

anchor.surface_text: When making the assessee two sums of Rs. 63,954 and Rs. 76,836. The sum of Rs. 63,954 was added in respect of the market value, as calculated by the Income-tax Officer, of the goods which were in the factory in the process of companyversion from gur into sugar. In the return filed by the assessee this stock of goods in process was number included at all.

facts.text: Closing stock of goods in process was 7,956 maunds, opening was 850 maunds.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer found that at the close of the relevant account year the stock of goods in process which had number been shown in the return companysisted of 7,956 maunds and the companyresponding stock of goods in process at the beginning of the account year was 850 maunds.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer added Rs. 63,954 being price of 7,106 maunds difference at Rs. 9 per maund.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer added a sum of Rs. 63,954 being the price of 7,106 maunds, the difference between the opening and the closing stock. The price was fixed at the rate of Rs. 9 per maund.

facts.text: Rs. 76,836 added back as wrongly shown as expenditure for excise duty, sales made in preceding year, assessee on mercantile system.

anchor.surface_text: The second sum of Rs. 76,836 was added back on the ground that it had been wrongly shown as expenditure in respect of excise duty in the account year, when the sales in respect of which this duty was paid had been made in the preceding year. It was held that as the assessee maintained accounts on the mercantile system of accounting, this excise duty should have been debited as expenditure number in the account year but in the preceding year.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner against both items.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in respect of both these items and urged certain points in support of its appeal which need number be stated here.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the appeal by order dated July 8, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner did number accept the companytentions urged on behalf of the assessee and rejected the appeal by his order dated July 8, 1946.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner issued notice under section 28(3) on July 5, 1946 for penalty under section 28(1)(c) re stock and excise duty.

anchor.surface_text: On July 5, 1946, however, he issued a numberice to the assessee under section 28(3) of the Income-tax Act asking it to show cause why a penalty under section 28(1)(c) should number be imposed on it on the ground that it had companycealed the particulars of its income or deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of its income, inasmuch as the stock of good in process amounting to 7,106 maunds was number accounted for and a sum of Rs. 76,836 on account of excise duty relating to another year was debited against the profits of the year of account.

facts.text: Assessee furnished explanation to notice on July 22, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: On July 22, 1946, the assessee furnished an explanation in answer to the numberice.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner imposed penalty of Rs. 50,000 by order dated January 21, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: This was companysidered by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who, by his order dated January 21, 1947, rejected the explanation furnished by the assessee and imposed a penalty of Rs. 50,000 on it.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal against assessment order and penalty order.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee went up in appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal (hereinafter referred to as the Tribunal) both against the order of assessment companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the order imposing a penalty under section 28(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Tribunal reduced addition for stock to Rs. 42,636 at Rs. 6 per maund.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal from the assessment order, the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the valuation of 7,106 maunds of goods in process should be made at Rs. 6 per maund instead of Rs. 9 as fixed by the Income-tax Officer and companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The amount of Rs. 63,954 was accordingly reduced to Rs. 42,636.

facts.text: Tribunal held Rs. 76,836 not expenditure of relevant year but allowable in 1941-42.

anchor.surface_text: As to the second sum of Rs. 76,836 the Tribunal held that the Income-tax Officer companyrectly found that that sum was number an expenditure in the relevant year of account, but numbere the less it was an expenditure incurred in the business and should have been allowed for the year to which it appertained.

facts.text: Tribunal reduced penalty to Rs. 43,000, order dated August 7, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: As to the penalty imposed under section 28(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, the Tribunal held that the penalty was rightly imposed but reduced the quantum of penalty to Rs. 43,000. Thereafter, the assessee moved the Tribunal for referring three questions of law which, according to it, arose out of the Tribunals order.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question No. 3 to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: One of these questions, question No. 3, we have already set out at the beginning of this judgment, being the question which the Tribunal referred to the High Court.

facts.text: Tribunal refused to refer two other questions as findings of fact.

anchor.surface_text: The other two questions were ... These two questions the Tribunal refused to refer to the High Court on the ground that they related to findings of fact and did number involve any questions of law.

facts.text: High Court rejected assessee's application under section 66(4) and (5) to direct Tribunal to state case on other questions.

anchor.surface_text: When the reference came to the High Court on the third question on a case being stated by the Income-tax, the assessee made an application to the High Court under sub-section (4) and (5) of section 66 and prayed that the Tribunal be asked to state a case on the other two questions also, questions as to which the Tribunal had refused to make a reference. This application the High Court rejected.

facts.text: High Court held Appellate Assistant Commissioner legally justified in issuing notice under section 28 re Rs. 76,836.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court then dealt with the third question which had been referred to it by the Tribunal and held that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a numberice under section 28 of the Income-tax Act to the assessee in respect of the item of Rs. 76,836.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a notice under section 28 of the Income-tax Act in circumstances of the case of the applicant in respect of the item of Rs. 76,836?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a numberice under section 28 of the Income-tax Act in circumstances of the case of the applicant in respect of the item of Rs. 76,836 ? We may first state the relevant facts. The assessee, appellant before us, is a partnership firm which ran a sugar mill at Cawnpore and assessee for the manufacture of sugar involved the companyversion of gur into sugar.

issues.text: Whether in view of the finding that the stock of sugar in process has never been shown in the accounts under section 13 of the Income-tax Act and that the value of the closing stock of sugar in process in the preceding year i.e., 850 maunds of opening stock of sugar in process was deducted in computing the profits of the previous year, a penalty as contemplated under section 28 of the Income-tax Act could be imposed?

anchor.surface_text: The other two questions were Whether in view of the finding that the stock of sugar in process has never been shown in the accounts under section 13 of the Income- tax Act and that the value of the closing stock of sugar in process in the preceding year  i.e., 850 maunds of opening stock of sugar in process  was deducted in companyputing the profits of the previous year, a penalty as companytemplated under section 28 of the Income-tax Act companyld be imposed ?

issues.text: Whether in view of the finding under section 31(4) of the Income-tax Act in I. T. A. No. 1200 of 1946-47 recorded by the Tribunal by its order dated August 17, 1947, it was legally necessary to adduce any further evidence besides the said finding and the books of account of the applicant, inasmuch as the said finding was legally binding on the parties?

anchor.surface_text: Whether in view of the finding under section 31 4  of the Income- tax Act in I. T. A. No. 1200 of 1946-47 recorded by the Tribunal by its order dated August 17, 1947, it was legally necessary to adduce any further evidence besides the said finding and the books of account of the applicant, inasmuch as the said finding was legally binding on the parties ? These two questions the Tribunal refused to refer to the High Court on the ground that they related to findings of fact and did number involve any questions of law.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in rejecting the assessee's application under sub-sections (4) and (5) of section 66 to direct the Tribunal to state a case on the other two questions refused by it?

anchor.surface_text: the assessee made an application to the High Court under sub-section  4  and  5  of section 66 and prayed that the Tribunal be asked to state a case on the other two questions also, questions as to which the Tribunal had refused to make a reference. This application the High Court rejected. The High Court then dealt with the third question which had been referred to it by the Tribunal and held that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a numberice under section 28 of the Income-tax Act to the assessee in respect of the item of Rs. 76,836.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal before us the learned advocate for the assessee has been unable to show that the answer given by the High Court to the third question, which was the only question referred to the High Court, was in any way incorrect. Section 28 of the Income-tax Act in terms enables the Appellate Assistant Commissioner to take action under that section if in person has, inter alia, concealed the particulars of his income or deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of such income.

arguments.claim: Sub-section (4) of section 66 states clearly that if the High Court is not satisfied that the statements in a case referred under the section are sufficient [...] the court may refer the case back to the Tribunal to make such additions thereto or alterations therein

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree. Sub-section 4 of section 66 states clearly that if the High Court is not satisfied that the statements in a case referred under the section are sufficient to enable it to determine the question raised thereby, the court may refer the case back to the Tribunal to make such additions thereto or alterations therein as the court may direct in that behalf.

arguments.claim: under sub-section (5) it is open to the High Court, without raising new and different questions, to resettle or reframe the questions formulated by the Tribunal before answering them [...] These considerations, however, do not arise in the present case

Whether in view of the finding that the stock of sugar in process has never been shown in the accounts under section 13 of the Income-tax Act and that the value of the closing stock of sugar in process in the preceding year i.e., 850 maunds of opening stock of sugar in process was deducted in computing the profits of the previous year, a penalty as contemplated under section 28 of the Income-tax Act could be imposed?

anchor.surface_text: The other two questions were Whether in view of the finding that the stock of sugar in process has never been shown in the accounts under section 13 of the Income- tax Act and that the value of the closing stock of sugar in process in the preceding year  i.e., 850 maunds of opening stock of sugar in process  was deducted in computing the profits of the previous year, a penalty as contemplated under section 28 of the Income-tax Act could be imposed ?

arguments.claim: Whether in view of the finding under section 31(4) of the Income-tax Act in I. T. A. No. 1200 of 1946-47 recorded by the Tribunal by its order dated August 17, 1947, it was legally necessary to adduce any further evidence besides the said finding and the books of account of the applicant, inasmuch as the said finding was legally binding on the parties?

anchor.surface_text: Whether in view of the finding under section 31(4) of the Income- tax Act in I. T. A. No. 1200 of 1946-47 recorded by the Tribunal by its order dated August 17, 1947, it was legally necessary to adduce any further evidence besides the said finding and the books of account of the applicant, inasmuch as the said finding was legally binding on the parties ? These two questions the Tribunal refused to refer to the High Court on the ground that they related to findings of fact and did not involve any questions of law.

holdings.text: We are satisfied that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a notice under section 28 of the Income-tax Act against assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly point that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was within his right in taking action under section 28 of the Income-tax Act against the assessee when in the course of the appeal proceedings before him he was satisfied that the assessee had deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of its income in the sense that it debited a sum of Rs. 76,836 on account of excise duty, an expenditure which related to another year and could not be debited against the profits of the year under consideration. We are satisfied that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a notice under section the 28 of the Income-tax Act against assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text of s.28 expressly authorizes AAC to initiate penalty action upon finding concealment or deliberate inaccurate particulars during appeal; inaccurate debit of prior-year excise duty qualifies; High Court correctly applied.

holdings.text: it is not open to the assessee to make any grievance of the order of the High Court rejecting the petition under sub-sections (4) and (5) of section 66.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that it is not open to the assessee to make any grievance of the order of the High Court rejecting the petition under sub-sections (4) and (5) of section 66. Those sub sections were of no assistance to the assessee in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s66(4) permits only additions/alterations to enable determination of referred question, not compelling new case on refused fact questions; distinct from s66(2) for refused references; s66(5) allows reframing only referred questions; first and third questions distinct, no implicit coverage.

holdings.text: Sub-section (4) of section 66 cannot do service for sub-section (2) thereof.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree. Sub-section (4) of section 66 states clearly that if the High Court is not satisfied that the statements in a case referred under the section are sufficient to enable it to determine the question raised thereby, the court may refer the case back to the Tribunal to make such additions thereto or alterations therein as the court may direct in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction: s66(4) addresses sufficiency of referred case statements; s66(2) remedies refusal to refer; cannot substitute.

holdings.text: under sub-section (5) it is open to the High Court, without raising new and different questions, to resettle or reframe the questions formulated by the Tribunal before answering them so as to bring out the real issue between the parties, and the High Court may even decide a point of law, which is implicit in or covered by the question referred by the Tribunal, no additional facts being necessary to support the point.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites prior decisions on scope of s66(5); distinguishes as inapplicable here since questions distinct and refused as fact.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

edges.explanation: Holding h1 expressly states satisfaction that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing the notice under section 28, directly addressing issue i1.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly point that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was within his right in taking action under section 28 of the Income-tax Act against the assessee when in the course of the appeal proceedings before him he was satisfied that the assessee had deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of its income in the sense that it debited a sum of Rs. 76,836 on account of excise duty, an expenditure which related to another year and could not be debited against the profits of the year under consideration. We are satisfied that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a notice under section the 28 of the Income-tax Act against assessee.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that it is not open to the assessee to make any grievance of the order of the High Court rejecting the petition under sub-sections (4) and (5) of section 66. Those sub sections were of no assistance to the assessee in the present case.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.
